reference: Pochet, Yves, and Laurence A. Wolsey. 'Production Planning by Mixed Integer Programming.' Springer Series in Operations Research and Financial Engineering (2006).

### Mathematical Model
Consider sets T (time periods), P (products), and M (machines) with the following:
- **Decision Variables**:
  - x_{t,p}: Number of units of product p to manufacture in period t
  - s_{t,p}: Number of units of product p to store in period t
  - y_{t,p}: Number of units of product p to sell in period t
- **Parameters**:
  - Ï€_p: Profit per unit of product p
  - h: Holding cost per unit per period
  - r_{m,p}: Time required on machine m per unit of product p
  - n_m: Number of machines of type m installed in the factory
  - c_m: Capacity of machine m (hours per period)
  - d_{t,m}: Machines of type m down for maintenance in period t
  - I_max: Maximum inventory capacity
  - S_{t,p}: Maximum sales for product p in period t
  - S_{target}: Target inventory level for each product at end of horizon

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Maximize} && \sum_{t,p} \pi_p y_{t,p} - \sum_{t,p} h s_{t,p} \\
&\text{Subject to} && x_{0,p} = y_{0,p} + s_{0,p} && \forall p \\
& && s_{t-1,p} + x_{t,p} = y_{t,p} + s_{t,p} && \forall t>0, p \\
& && \sum_p r_{m,p} x_{t,p} \leq c_m(n_m - d_{t,m}) && \forall t,m \\
& && s_{t,p} \leq I_{max} && \forall t,p \\
& && y_{t,p} \leq S_{t,p} && \forall t,p \\
& && s_{T,p} = S_{target} && \forall p \\
& && x_{t,p}, s_{t,p}, y_{t,p} \geq 0 && \forall t,p
\end{aligned}
$$
natural_language_example:
A furniture factory produces three types of items using multiple machines:
* Products:
  - Tables: profit $200/unit, requires 2 hours on grinder, 1 hour on drill
  - Chairs: profit $150/unit, requires 1 hour on grinder, 1.5 hours on borer
  - Cabinets: profit $300/unit, requires 3 hours on grinder, 2 hours on drill
* Machine Resources:
  - 4 Grinders: 160 hours/month each
  - 2 Vertical Drills: 160 hours/month each
  - 1 Borer: 160 hours/month
* Constraints:
  - Storage limit: 100 units per product
  - Monthly sales limits: Tables (50), Chairs (80), Cabinets (30)
  - Machine maintenance: 1 grinder down in month 2, 1 drill down in month 4
  - Storage cost: $20 per unit per month
  - End-horizon targets: Tables (20), Chairs (30), Cabinets (15)

The goal is to:
1. Determine optimal production quantities
2. Plan inventory levels
3. Schedule sales
4. Maximize total profit over 6 months
5. Meet end-of-horizon inventory targets
